Class ec.tables.Table 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.tables.Table
public class Table
extends Object
Like a java.util.Hashtable, except that it admits nulls for both keys and values, and so must indicate absence differently. If you want strict compatibility, use SimTable, which wraps this Table in a compatible simulation of java.util.Hashtable.

mySizeThreshold 
 int mySizeThreshold
The current size threshold for the table, that is, the number of elements to hold before growing. It is calculated as myNumSlots * myLoadFactor.

myLoadFactor 
 float myLoadFactor
The load factor for the table.

containsKey 
 public boolean containsKey(Object key)

Parameters:

Returns:

get 
 public Object get(Object key) throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the value to which the key is mapped in this table. Unlike java.util.Dictionary, Table doesn't indicate a lookup failure by returning null, since null is a valid value. Table throws an exception instead.

get 
 public Object get(Object key,
                   Object instead)
Returns the value to which the key is mapped in this table. If key is not mapped, return 'instead' instead.

put 
 public void put(Object key,
                 Object value)
Like 'put' of three arguments, but defaults 'strict' to false.

put 
 public void put(Object key,
                 Object value,
                 boolean strict)
Causes 'key' to map to 'value'. If 'strict' is false (the default), this will overwrite a previous value if necessary. If 'strict' is true, this only succeeds if there is not already an association for 'key' in the Table. If 'strict' is true and there is an already an association, even to the same value, this throws an Exception instead (XXX currently an IllegalArgumentException) and leaves the Table unmodified.

Unlike Dictionary, this doesn't return the old value. If you want it, use 'get' first.

putAll 
 public void putAll(Object keys,
                    Object elements,
                    boolean strict)
A convenience, and a bit of a hack, for initializing Tables from a kind of data that can easily be expressed literally and composably in Java. Let's call this kind of data a LitTree. A LitTree is a tree whose internal nodes are arrays, and whose leaves are non-arrays. The members of a LitTree are only the non-array leaves.

(The hacky part is that a LitTree cannot represent an array object as a member. It's like defining a string format that can't quote quote. Oh well, it's only a convenience.)

Both 'keys' and 'elements' are LitTrees. When their structure is parallel, corresponding leaf key-element members are put into this Table. The other allowed case is for a 'keys' subtree to match a single 'elements' leaf member, in which case an association is put into the Table from each of the leaf keys in that subtree to that same element. No other cases are allowed.

putPairs 
 public void putPairs(Object pairs[][],
                      boolean strict)
Helps with another convenient literal pattern, an array (not a LitTree) of key-element pairs. Each key-element pair is put into the Table

putMulti 
 public void putMulti(Object mappings[][],
                      boolean strict)
Helps with a literal pattern for expressing multi-valued mappings. 'mappings' is an array (not a LitTree) of maps, where a map is an array whose zeroth member is a key and whose remaining members are the elements the key maps to. Since Table only represents single-valued mapping directly, the multi-valued mapping is represented as a Table that maps the key onto a Table whose domain is the set of elements.

remove 
 public void remove(Object key)
Defaults 'strict' to false

remove 
 public void remove(Object key,
                    boolean strict)
Removes the given key (or its equivalent, according to the equal function) from the collection. If 'strict' is false (the default), this does nothing if 'key' is not currently a key in the collection. If 'strict' is true and 'key' isn't already there to be removed, this throws an Exception (XXX currently an IllegalArgumentException).

Unlike Dictionary, this does not return the old value. If you want this for a Table, use 'get' first.

Parameters:
key - the key to remove
removeAll 
 public void removeAll(Object keys,
                       boolean strict)
'keys' is a LitTree (as defined in Table.putAll()). All members of the LitTree are removed from this Table

See Also:
putAll
clear 
 public void clear()
Removes all associations from this table, leaving this table empty.

Rather than doing a write-fault (which would make a private copy to be immediately dropped) this decrements the sharing count and re-initializes.

clone 
 public Object clone()
Unlike java.util.Hashtable, this part efficiently makes a lazy copy by copy-on-write sharing. Modify operations on a shared Table then cause the delayed copy to happen.

Overrides:
clone in class Object
weakness 
 public int weakness()
Describes the weakness attributes of this table by returning one of STRONG, KEYS_WEAK, VALUES_WEAK, or BOTH_WEAK.

isIdentity 
 public boolean isIdentity()
Does this Table compare keys based on EQ identity rather than equality?

garbageCollect 
 void garbageCollect(int slot)
Note that this isn't a write fault! Called by some appropriate garbage collector to collect an association whose weak reference points at something being collected. The actions of this method are considered to be an atomic part of the garbage collector.

keyType 
 public Class keyType()
All keys in this collection must be of this type

valueType 
 public Class valueType()
All values in this table must be of this type
